Dustin, the other reason behind the wire-like cocoon has to do with the fact the ants in that region have no problem cutting through thin, paper-like cocoons with their mandibles, whereas the thicker, rope-like wire cocoons present more of a challenge. It doesn't stop smaller ants, but the hard exterior shell of the pupae does stop the smaller ants. It does, however, stop larger ants that might be able to get through the hard exterior shell of the pupae.

This is actually a "layered defense" strategy that evolved over time in order to deal with two different threats!

And yes, it lets the water through, but remember, it rains a lot in many areas of North America, as well, ans the paper-like cocoons don't seem to fill up with water. In fact, they're built to shed water, breathing through a tiny hole at the bottom when the sides are wet. That's the same hole you see much more clearly in your net-like cocoon.

We can also deduce the way it evolved to this state using this explanation. Some specimen were making bigger breathing holes in their cocoons than others, using less material, therefore saving energy and time(less time waiting to get eaten, less specimens get eaten). The tendency was for more & bigger holes, and mother nature regulated this until it evolved into current, beautiful form.

3D printer hobbyist here, I think there is also another reason. Such mostly hollow stuctures are more effective when it comes to stiffness to mass ratio. Your fancy insect can conserve time and energy required to produce material and the cocoon itself by that strategy.
